course_title: Short Course: Linear Regression and Model Selection
course_description: A concise graduate-level introduction to linear regression, covering model formulation, interpretation, model building, variable screening, and diagnostic assessment. Designed for researchers and professionals needing a rigorous refresher.
learning_outcomes: Formulate simple and multiple linear regression models and articulate their assumptions.
Interpret regression coefficients, including partial, interaction, and categorical effects.
Evaluate model utility using hypothesis tests, R-squared metrics, and prediction accuracy.
Identify when additive models fail and implement interaction or polynomial terms.
Incorporate qualitative predictors using indicator (dummy) variables.
Apply principles of parsimony and evidence-based model building.
Use AIC, multicollinearity diagnostics, and stepwise procedures for model selection.
Perform residual analysis, identify influential observations, and apply transformations.

modules.title: Linear statistical models
topics: Purpose of statistical modelling and framing predictors/outcomes
Linear prediction as E[Y]=alpha+beta X with slope/intercept interpretation
Role of random error: mean-zero, constant-variance, and normality ideas
Specification of the simple linear model and visualising simulated data

modules.title: Simple Linear Regression (SLR)
topics: Deciding when SLR is appropriate
Fitting models to data via least squares and residuals
Estimating coefficients with lm() and visual checks
Variance estimation, residual standard error, correlation, and R-squared
Inference for the slope: t-tests, confidence intervals, and p-values
Prediction for Y: confidence intervals and prediction intervals

modules.title: Multiple Linear Regression (MLR)
topics: When to extend SLR to multiple predictors
MLR model structure with continuous predictors and partial coefficients
Least-squares estimation and inference in higher dimensions
Global F-test for overall usefulness
Multicollinearity considerations
Adjusted R-squared, model fit, and interpreting summary(lm) output

modules.title: Model Building and Variable Screening
topics: Exploratory analysis and theory-driven model formulation
Systematic vs random variation, adequacy, and parsimony
Choosing first- vs second-order functional forms; interactions and curvature
Qualitative predictors: dummy coding, baselines, ANOVA-style tests, and mixed predictors
Variable screening: multicollinearity checks, AIC, and stepwise strategies
Balancing prediction and explanation while guarding against overfitting/extrapolation

modules.title: Regression Pitfalls and Diagnostics
topics: Common pitfalls: misspecification, extrapolation, overfitting, and leverage outliers
Residual plots versus fitted values and predictors
Diagnosing nonconstant variance and nonlinearity
Assessing normality of residuals
Standardised residuals, leverage, Cook's distance
Transformations including Box-Cox
Handling outliers and influential observations

modules.title: Case Study: NAPLAN
topics: Defining the research question
Importing data
Exploratory plot
Fitting the least-squares model
Model refinement and interpretation
Reporting the results

assessment_options.exercises: Short practical or theoretical exercises linked to each module.

capstone_project.description: A modelling project requiring exploratory analysis, model formulation, model selection, diagnostics, and interpretation.
components: Model selection using AIC and diagnostic checks
Written or presented interpretation of results

references: Mendenhall & Sincich, A Second Course in Statistics: Regression Analysis
STAT210/410 lecture materials on MLR, Model Building, Variable Screening, and Residual Analysis
